channel.title: NYT > Science
channel.copyright: Copyright 2025 The New York Times Company

item.title: Who’s the Parasite Now? This Newly Discovered ‘Fairy Lantern’ Flower.
item.description: Found in a forest outside Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia, the plant steals nutrients from subterranean fungi.
item.dc:creator: Douglas Main

item.title: In Pursuit of the Monarch’s Magnetic Sense
item.description: The magnetic compass is the last unknown sense in migrating animals. For some scientists, the monarch butterfly is leading the way.
item.dc:creator: Alexa Robles-Gil and Mark Felix
item.media:credit: Mark Felix for The New York Times

item.title: Why Scientists Are Performing Brain Surgery on Monarchs
item.description: Scientists in Texas are studying monarch butterflies to understand how they navigate thousands of miles, possibly by sensing Earth’s magnetic field. Alexa Robles-Gil explains how researchers are examining the butterflies’ brains to find answers.
item.dc:creator: Alexa Robles-Gil, Leila Medina, Joey Sendaydiego and Mark Felix

item.title: Puzzle Designers Search for That ‘Satisfying Click’
item.description: For prizewinning puzzle creators, the devilish ideas are in the details.
item.dc:creator: Siobhan Roberts

item.title: Some of the World’s Atomic Clocks Were Off Last Week (by 5-Millionths of a Second)
item.description: How some of the world’s most precise clocks missed a very small beat.
item.dc:creator: Mike Ives and Adeel Hassan
item.media:credit: R. Eskalis/National Institute of Standards and Technology
item.media:description: A cesium fountain clock at the National Institute of Standards and Technology in Boulder, Colo.

item.title: This City’s Best Winter Show Is in Its Pitch-Dark Skies
item.description: A heritage of dark sky preservation means residents of Flagstaff welcome the season’s longer nights with prolonged views of the stars.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Emily Elconin for The New York Times

item.title: The Meek Really Did Inherit the Earth, at Least Among Ants
item.description: How did ants take over the world? The answer may be skin deep.
item.dc:creator: Cara Giaimo

item.title: Museum of the Earth and Its Fossil Collection Fight Their Own Extinction
item.description: A funding crisis at the Museum of the Earth and the Paleontological Research Institution in Ithaca, N.Y., could scatter priceless specimens and end nearly a century of pioneering research.
item.dc:creator: Becky Ferreira and Kristian Thacker
item.media:credit: Kristian Thacker for The New York Times

item.title: NASA Webb Telescope Discovers Lemon-Shaped Planet, the ‘Stretchiest’ Ever Seen
item.description: An unusual object orbiting a rapidly spinning star might be a new phenomenon in the universe.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan O’Callaghan
item.media:description: An artist’s impression of the lemon-shaped world, which astronomers say would be red because of dust and soot from the carbon in its atmosphere.

item.title: Trump Tosses Lifelines to the Struggling Coal Industry
item.description: The Energy Department ordered two coal-burning power plants to remain open, and the Environmental Protection Agency gave utilities more time to tackle toxic coal ash.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Friedman and Maxine Joselow
item.media:description: Chris Wright, the energy secretary, ordered that two Indiana coal plants, scheduled to close soon, keep running until early 2026.

item.title: U.S. Takes a Step Toward Approving Seabed Mining in International Waters
item.description: The federal government said it would hold hearings next month on controversial applications to mine the ocean floor.
item.dc:creator: Sachi Kitajima Mulkey
item.media:credit: Tamir Kalifa for The New York Times
item.media:description: A ship chartered by the Metals Company in 2021 to assess the potential of seabed mining.

item.title: Trump May Give SpaceX Some Land In A Texas Wildlife Refuge
item.description: In exchange for the land in Texas, the rocket and satellite company would give the government some of its own property nearby, documents show.
item.dc:creator: Maxine Joselow
item.media:credit: Meridith Kohut for The New York Times
item.media:description: SpaceX’s launchpad near Boca Chica Beach in South Texas.

item.title: The Pentagon and A.I. Giants Have a Weakness. Both Need China’s Batteries, Badly.
item.description: As warfare is reinvented in Ukraine, and Silicon Valley races to maintain its A.I. lead, China’s battery dominance is raising alarms far beyond the auto industry.
item.dc:creator: Hiroko Tabuchi, Brad Plumer and Harry Stevens
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Trump Administration Loosens Protections for Iconic Greater Sage Grouse
item.description: The government moves to make it easier to drill, mine and graze on 50 million acres of land in the West.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Friedman
item.media:description: The greater sage grouse, a large chicken-like bird known for the males’ flamboyant courtship dance, is considered a key indicator of the health of an ecosystem that spans 11 Western states.

item.title: How Blocking Illegal ‘Ghost’ Roads Could Protect Tropical Forests
item.description: New research tries to anticipate road building to identify areas in the Amazon, Asia and Africa that are likely to face deforestation.
item.dc:creator: Sachi Kitajima Mulkey
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences
item.media:description: A fire in the Amazon in northern Brazil.

item.title: Mercedes to Pay $150 Million Over Claims It Cheated on Emissions Tests
item.description: It’s the latest in a decade-long scandal involving accusations that software “defeat devices” made diesel vehicles seem cleaner than they were.
item.dc:creator: Karen Zraick
item.media:credit: Charity Rachelle for The New York Times
item.media:description: Mercedes-Benz was accused of violating state laws against deceptive trade practices.

item.title: How Trump’s First Year Reshaped U.S. Energy and Climate Policy
item.description: The sweeping changes have affected everything from coal plant retirements to international diplomacy over shipping emissions.
item.dc:creator: Brad Plumer, Lisa Friedman, Maxine Joselow and Scott Dance
item.media:description: An “Unleashing American Energy” executive order signing at the White House in April.

item.title: Older Americans Quit Weight-Loss Drugs in Droves
item.description: In some studies, half of patients stopped taking GLP-1s within a year despite the benefits, citing the expense and side effects.
item.dc:creator: Paula Span

item.title: Overlooked No More: Inge Lehmann, Who Discovered the Earth’s Inner Core
item.description: She pointed to evidence that the Earth’s inner core was solid — not liquid, as scientists had believed — a discovery that was ahead of its time.
item.dc:creator: Dylan Loeb McClain

item.title: How to Watch the Ursids Winter Solstice Meteor Shower
item.description: The Ursids this weekend are a winter solstice light show.
item.dc:creator: Katrina Miller
item.media:description: A rendering of the orbit followed by the Ursids meteor shower. The white line shows the shower’s path, and the bright blue line in the middle represents the Earth’s orbit.

item.title: Controversial Dakota Pipeline Gets a Big, Belated Government Boost
item.description: A delayed environmental review cleared the Dakota Access Pipeline to continue operating. Separately, a North Dakota judge expressed unusual exasperation over the tangled legal battles.
item.dc:creator: Karen Zraick
item.media:description: Activists in France earlier this year supporting Greenpeace, which is fighting a verdict against it that could bankrupt its U.S. operations.

item.title: A Somber Mood at Science Meeting as Trump Budget Cuts Continue
item.description: News of the breakup of a leading science institution rippled through an annual gathering of Earth, ocean and space scientists. Many say American science is suffering under the Trump administration.
item.dc:creator: Eric Niiler
item.media:description: The National Center for Atmospheric Research in Boulder, Colo., is one of the world’s premier climate and weather science institutions.

item.title: F.D.A. Turmoil Keeps Spotlight on Its Commissioner
item.description: The agency’s high-level turnover and conflicting policy decisions on drug oversight have fueled concerns about the leadership of Dr. Marty Makary.
item.dc:creator: Christina Jewett
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:credit: Al Drago for The New York Times
item.media:description: Dr. Marty Makary, the F.D.A. commissioner, has faced intense criticism as the agency undergoes top-level turnover in critical areas like drug approvals.

item.title: Suspect in MIT Professor’s Death Was an Ex-Classmate from Portugal, Prosecutors Say
item.description: Nuno F.G. Loureiro, the professor, and the man suspected in his killing attended the same physics program in Portugal during the 1990s.
item.dc:creator: Pooja Salhotra, Francesca Regalado, Azam Ahmed and Sarah Mervosh
item.media:description: People gathering outside the home of Nuno F.G. Loureiro in Brookline, Mass., on Tuesday.

item.title: Trump Moves to End Gender-Related Care for Minors, Threatening Hospitals That Offer It
item.description: Proposed new rules would punish the hospitals by pulling all federal financing. Advocates say lawsuits will follow.
item.dc:creator: Azeen Ghorayshi, Amy Harmon and Reed Abelson
item.category: Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services
item.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times
item.media:description: Health Secretary Robert F. Kennedy Jr., with President Trump and Mehmet Oz, the Medicaid and Medicare services administrator, in the White House in September.

item.title: She Tracked Fish That Coastal Communities Depend On. Then She Was Fired From NOAA.
item.description: Ana Vaz monitored crucial fish stocks in the Southeast and the Gulf of Mexico until she lost her job at NOAA.
item.dc:creator: Austyn Gaffney
item.media:credit: Dado Galdieri for The New York Times
